title: Daryl Hall and John Oates quietly resolve lawsuit over sale of joint venture. What to know
description: The lawsuit over a business dispute between the members of the legendary rock duo Hall & Oates ended Aug. 12.
content:
The band may not be back together, but Daryl Hall and John Oates at least aren't in a court battle anymore.

The lawsuit over a business dispute between the members of the legendary rock duo Hall & Oates ended Aug. 12, court documents show. Hall, who filed the lawsuit against Oates, his wife and a member of Oates' trust in November 2023, dismissed his claims in Davidson County Chancery Court on Aug. 11.

The lawsuit concerned what Hall said was Oates' plan to sell a portion of their joint venture Whole Oats Enterprises to a third party. Hall argued that sale would violate a business agreement the two musicians reached on Oct. 15, 2021. Hall sued Oates as well as his wife, Aimee Oates, and Richard Flynn, who are both co-trustees of The John W. Oates TISA Trust and were parties to the October 2021 agreement.

The claims were resolved in arbitration outside court, so it's not clear in court filings if the sale went through. A possible clue could lie in how the case was legally dismissed from court.

At Hall's request, the case was dismissed without prejudice. That's legalese meaning Hall could refile a lawsuit over the same issue later, compared with a dismissal with prejudice, which would end the issue once and for all.

The sale of Whole Oats Enterprises to publisher Primary Wave Music was temporarily blocked by Chancellor Russell Perkins in late November 2023 until an arbitrator had a chance to weigh in.

Attorneys for Hall or Oates and the other defendants did not respond to emails sent prior to publication. The musicians' publicists also did not return requests for comment.

The duo, known for hits like "Maneater," "Rich Girl" and "Out of Touch," is likely never reuniting, based on Oates' statements to Rolling Stone for a 2024 article.

In the early days of the lawsuit, the two lashed out in court filings. Hall called Oates' actions "the ultimate partnership betrayal." Oates retorted that Hall's accusations were "inflammatory, outlandish and inaccurate."

More: The Daryl Hall and John Oates legal battle explained

Have questions about the justice system? Evan Mealins is the justice reporter for The Tennessean. Contact him with questions, tips or story ideas at emealins@tennessean.com.

This article originally appeared on Nashville Tennessean: Daryl Hall, John Oates resolve lawsuit in arbitration

Hall, who filed a lawsuit against Oates' wife, wife, and a member of their trust, argued that the sale of their joint venture, Whole Oats Enterprises, would violate a business agreement reached in October 2021. The lawsuit was resolved in arbitration outside court, allowing Hall to refile the lawsuit later than a dismissal with prejudice. It is unclear if the sale went through. The case was dismissed without prejudice, meaning Hall could potentially refile another lawsuit later.
shortSummary: A lawsuit between Daryl Hall and John Oates over the sale of their joint venture ended in arbitration, with Hall's claims dismissed without prejudice.

Hall & Oates lawsuit: Judge sides with Daryl Hall, blocks John Oates' attempt to sell
After an attorney for one half of musical duo Hall & Oates read a draft order to block his client’s sale of shares in a joint venture Thursday morning, he had a simple message for the judge: I can’t go for that.
But Chancellor Russell T. Perkins’ order filed Thursday afternoon is pretty clear.
No can do.
In at least a short-term win for musician Daryl Hall, Perkins entered a temporary injunction Thursday that means musician John Oates still cannot sell his shares of Whole Oats Enterprises, the joint business venture between Hall and Oates, to third party publisher Primary Wave Music.
The injunction blocks the sale until a private arbitrator hired to weigh in on the dispute decides whether a restraining order in the arbitration is appropriate, or until Feb. 17, 2024, at 1 p.m., whichever comes first. Perkins called the injunction he entered "provisional," as it's meant to maintain the status quo until an arbitrator has a chance to rule.
Hall, who filed a lawsuit against his longtime musical partner in Davidson Chancery Court on Nov. 16, says in court records that Oates attempted to make the sale to the publisher without his approval, in violation of a business agreement between the two.
For those out of touch: The Daryl Hall and John Oates legal battle explained ahead of Nashville court date
Hall says he learned of Oates’ plan to sell his shares of Whole Oats on Oct. 20, just days before Hall was scheduled to embark on an international tour.
“I was blindsided by this information,” Hall wrote.
If the sale had gone through, Hall says he would've been "forced to partner with an entity that I did not agree to partner with, and whose business model does not comport with my views," writing that "there is no amount of money that could compensate" him for that.
Hall contacted an arbitration company on Nov. 9 to resolve the dispute, his attorneys say, but by Nov. 16, still no arbitrator had been selected. Hall said he feared that Oates would make the sale as soon as Nov. 20, so he sued. Perkins issued a temporary restraining order on Nov. 16 blocking the sale for 15 days.
A briefing in the lawsuit from Wednesday night says that the parties finally selected an arbitrator on Monday.
The two traded blows in personal declarations filed in the court case on Wednesday, with Hall calling Oates' alleged actions the "ultimate partnership betrayal."
Oates, on the other hand, has called Hall's claims "inflammatory, outlandish and inaccurate," and contends that he did nothing wrong in trying to sell his shares to Primary Wave. His attorney Tim Warnock from Nashville firm Loeb & Loeb said Thursday morning that Oates proceeded “exactly as he was allowed to proceed,” which drew a head shake from Christine Lepera, the New York lawyer on Hall’s legal team who was in Nashville for the hearing.
Who is right is still a mystery to the public at this point, since many of the documents in the case have been placed under seal. Perkins ruled from the bench Thursday morning that the seal will stay in place, meaning the details of the duo’s business dealings remain for private eyes.
More: 'Outlandish and inaccurate': John Oates lashes back at Daryl Hall in new court filing
Evan Mealins is the justice reporter for The Tennessean. Contact him at emealins@gannett.com or follow him on X, formerly known as Twitter, @EvanMealins.

'Outlandish and inaccurate': John Oates lashes back at Daryl Hall in new court filing
Days after Daryl Hall filed a lawsuit and received a temporary restraining order against his past musical partner John Oates, a new document reveals Hall's feelings about John Oates' recent business undertakings with their joint venture. Hall's impassioned declaration calls Oates' actions "the ultimate partnership betrayal."
Late Wednesday evening, a new filing from Oates lashed back against Hall, calling the accusations "inflammatory, outlandish, and inaccurate."
The two musicians, previously duo Hall & Oates, are known for songs "Maneater" and "You Make My Dreams (Come True)."
Below, The Tennessean sums up the facts of the case and Daryl Hall's publicly-available statement on the dispute filed in Nashville Wednesday afternoon.
Why is Daryl Hall suing John Oates?
Hall sued longtime music partner John Oates on Nov. 16, days after he says he also began a private arbitration against Oates.
The dispute centers around Oates’ alleged attempt to sell his half of the assets of the duo’s joint venture, Whole Oats Enterprises, to a third-party publishing company called Primary Wave Music.
Hall contends that such a sale would violate a business agreement they reached in 2021, which he says requires the other partner give written approval to any sale — approval that Hall is adamant he will not give in this case.
Oates' wife Aimee Oates and Richard Flynn, who are both co-trustees of The John W. Oates TISA Trust and were parties to the October 2021 agreement governing Whole Oats Enterprises, are also named defendants in Hall's lawsuit.
While Hall began the process of arbitration on Nov. 9, no arbitrator had yet been selected and therefore could not stop a potential sale of Whole Oates Enterprises, according to court documents. Fearing that Oates would complete the sale as soon as Nov. 20, per court records, Hall filed the lawsuit seeking an order blocking the sale.
Chancellor Russell T. Perkins issued a temporary restraining order the same day the lawsuit was filed. That restraining order is set to expire after 15 days.
Hall’s attorneys have asked for a more permanent type of court order called a temporary injunction that would block the sale of Whole Oats Enterprises for a longer period of time after its expiration.
Attorneys will argue whether Perkins should issue that injunction at the hearing scheduled for Thursday, Nov. 30, at 9:30 a.m.
More: The Daryl Hall and John Oates legal battle explained ahead of Nashville court date
What did Daryl Hall say about the lawsuit in his declaration from Nov. 29?
The declaration from Hall features 21 points, each of which details his understanding of a series of events that led to the suit and restraining order.
Hall's statement says: "While falsely contending over the last several months that the Oates Trust wanted to maintain ownership in [Whole Oats Enterprises], John Oates and the Co-Trustees engaged in the ultimate partnership betrayal.
"They surreptitiously sought to sell half of the [Whole Oats Enterprises] assets without obtaining my written approval. Mutual approval over the power to sell partnership assets is inarguably the most important consent in any partnership."
He adds that, "there is no amount of money that could compensate me for being forced to partner with an entity that I did not agree to partner with, and whose business model does not comport with my views," writing that the harm from being forced to partner with Primary Wave "is unimaginable."
Hall closed out his declaration by writing that he was "deeply troubled by the deterioration of my relationship with, and trust in, John Oates.
"His and the Oates Trust’s actions— entering into an agreement for the sale of their WOE partnership interest, in breach of our partnership agreement, without my written approval and while intentionally concealing it from me while we were actively engaging in the mediation process over the very same assets — has caused me an enormous amount of distress," Hall wrote. "Without the relief requested being granted, John Oates and the Oates Trust will have forced a sale of [Whole Oates Enterprises] assets and invoked attendant obligations to my great detriment and without my permission."
Hall declared his statement under penalty of perjury.
In his response late Wednesday, Oates denied the accusations.
"I am tremendously disappointed that Daryl Hall decided to file his declaration from our private arbitration in this proceeding and make inflammatory, outlandish, and inaccurate statements about me," Oates said in the filing, later adding: "I have no idea who or what is motivating Daryl to take these steps and make such salacious statements, but I am deeply hurt."
What is next for the Hall vs. Oates case?
Reporters from The Tennessean will be present at the Nashville proceeding on Nov. 30 and will report on changes and updates in the case.
Evan Mealins is the justice reporter for The Tennessean. Contact him at emealins@gannett.com or follow him on X, formerly known as Twitter, @EvanMealins.

The Daryl Hall and John Oates legal battle explained ahead of Nashville court date
In the wake of a lawsuit filed by Daryl Hall against former bandmate John Oates on Nov. 16, music fans were left in the dark about the rift between the two singer-songwriters.
Most of the details of the lawsuit were sealed until the judge released some documents, including a redacted copy of the complaint, last Wednesday. Many specifics of the case, filed in Davidson County Chancery Court, are still unknown.
The lawsuit follows a planned business deal by Oates to sell off part of the pair's joint venture.
Here's what you should know about Hall vs. Oates ahead of a proceeding in Nashville on Nov. 30.
What is Hall and Oates' relationship history?
Daryl Hall and John Oates comprise the pop duo Hall & Oates, which formed in the early 1970s in Philadelphia. The two are best known for hits "You Make My Dreams (Come True)," "Maneater" and "Rich Girl."
They duo never had a publicized split but have told media outlets they have been drifting apart over recent years. Both have been pursuing individual careers and distancing themselves from their hits of the past.
Why is Daryl Hall suing John Oates?
Daryl Hall is suing John Oates because of Oates' plan to sell a portion of their joint venture to a third party, which Hall says would violate a business agreement between the two musicians reached on Oct. 15, 2021.
Hall is suing to block the sale until an arbitrator weighs in on the issue. While Hall had already begun a private arbitration process before filing the lawsuit on Nov. 16, he feared that unless he sued, Oates would continue with the sale as soon as Nov. 20 because an arbitrator hadn't yet been selected.
The sale of shares of Whole Oats Enterprises LLP to Primary Wave Music cannot take place until the private arbitration process concludes or a temporary restraining order in the case expires.
Hall said in the complaint that he is also seeking damages "incurred as a result of Defendants' multiple breaches of" their business agreement.
Primary Wave already owns the copyright and music publishing interests for a variety of Hall & Oates' hits, like "Maneater" and "Private Eyes."
In a court filing on Nov. 29, Hall wrote an impassioned declaration calling Oates' recent undertakings with their joint venture "the ultimate partnership betrayal."
Oates responded with his own Declaration on the evening of Nov. 29, stating that Hall has made "inflammatory, outlandish, and inaccurate statements" about him.
Oates said, "I have no idea who or what is motivating Daryl to take these steps and make such salacious statements, but I am deeply hurt."
Why is there a restraining order?
Chancellor Russell T. Perkins issued a temporary restraining order on Nov. 16 prohibiting Oates from completing the sale of shares of Whole Oats Enterprises to Primary Wave.
Temporary restraining orders in Tennessee last up to 15 days, although they can be renewed by a judge. Hall has also asked the judge to issue a temporary injunction blocking the sale, which would last through the end of the case.
What does the lawsuit mean for John Oates and Daryl Hall?
Oates is currently not able to sell his shares of the joint venture.
Hall had to post a temporary restraining order bond of $50,000. The bond covers costs that may be suffered by a person who is found to have been wrongfully restrained.
Is Daryl Hall suing any other individuals in this case?
Oates' wife Aimee Oates and Richard Flynn, who are both co-trustees of The John W. Oates TISA Trust and were parties to the October 2021 agreement governing Whole Oats Enterprises, are also named defendants in Hall's lawsuit.
Summonses were issued to the Oates' at their Nashville home on Monday.
When is the next court date for Hall vs. Oates?
The motion for a temporary injunction is going to be heard on Nov. 30 at 9:30 a.m. in Perkins' courtroom in Nashville. Perkins will also hear arguments from the attorneys over whether to keep certain documents in the case under seal.
The gag order in the case will expire Thursday afternoon unless extended by Perkins.
Reporters from The Tennessean will be present for the hearing and will update information as new developments in the case occur.

John Oates Is Pretty Sure Hall & Oates Are Never, Ever Getting Back Together
When John Oates spoke to Rolling Stone in January 2020, he explained how balancing his time between massive Hall & Oates concerts with his longtime creative partner Daryl Hall and intimate solo gigs provided him with a dream life. “It keeps me balanced,” he said. “[When I tour solo], I carry my own gear. I show up with my guitar in my hand and put the amp in the back of my car. It’s real and I love it. Then I go out there with Daryl and we’re flying around in private planes and playing the Garden and doing all that. I love it.”
It was therefore a pretty big shock when, in November 2023, Hall accused Oates of committing the “ultimate partnership betrayal” by attempting to sell his share of their business without his permission in a legal filing that generated headlines all across the globe. They haven’t played a show together since October 2022. “[I am] deeply troubled by the deterioration of my relationship with, and trust in, John Oates,” Hall told the court. “His behavior has become adversarial and aggressive instead of professional and courteous.”
Oates wasn’t willing to discuss details of the ongoing legal battle when he spoke with RS recently about his new solo LP Reunion. But he did explain why his attitude toward Hall & Oates shifted so dramatically.
“I’ll tell you what changed,” he says. “During the pandemic, there were no more private planes. There were no more arena shows or even acoustic shows. It gave me a chance to step back. I had a chance to reevaluate things. My wife and I decided it was time to give back. We started the Oates Song Fest for Feeding America, and we fed 350,000 families with that. And then I was asked to do Movember, which was a men’s health movement. I just got out of the mode of getting back on stage with the big band and the big production.”
That big Hall & Oates production was at the center of his life for more than 50 years. He’s delivered hits like “Maneater,” “Private Eyes,” and “Kiss on My List” alongside Hall well over a thousand times each. “I understand why people come and want to hear the big hits,” he says. “Those songs are going to live forever. But I wanted to relegate them to the classic file that they’re in. And I wanted them to be heard in the best possible light, the way they were when the spark was on fire in the Seventies and Eighties. That’s when those songs really resonated. To keep playing them, for me, was no longer interesting. I just wanted to do something else.”
In his perfect world, the business dispute with Hall — what Oates calls “a very boring business issue” — would never have become public. “There’s always disputes when people are famous. People are always fascinated about the dynamics of a duo,” he says. “And to be quite honest, Daryl and I have a business partnership, and there was some things about the business that we disagreed with, which happens all the time in business. And we’re going to work it out.” (A rep for Hall did not respond to Rolling Stone‘s request for comment.)
Last year, Hall played a series of dates with Todd Rundgren. At the end of the night, they sang each other’s songs together, including the Hall & Oates 1979 classic “Wait for Me.” The lawsuit hit right before he flew out to begin a new leg of the tour in Asia, and Hall accused of Oates of trying to sabotage the tour. “This recent bad faith conduct by John Oates and the Oates Trust has created tremendous upheaval, harm, and difficulty in my life,” Hall wrote in a legal filing. “I believe that John Oates timed the Unauthorized Transaction to create the most harm to me.”
Oates says this is untrue. “That’s what he said?” Oates asks. “I didn’t even know he was going on tour. I had nothing to do with that. If that’s how he perceived it, then that’s how he perceived it. But, really honestly, I don’t follow him on social media. In fact, I don’t even know what he’s doing. I hope he’s doing well and I hope he’s having a time of his life, but it’s not part of my life.”
According to Oates, he was also unaware that Hall was touring America with Elvis Costello later this year until RS informed him of the news. “I’m really glad that, in a way, this situation has given him the opportunity to be himself,” Oates says. “And however he wants to show himself and perform and be creative as an individual, I think it’s great, because that’s what I want to do.”
Despite all the current drama, Hall & Oates never formally broke up — they just stopped booking concert dates — and Wikipedia lists the duo’s active years as “1970-present.” Should an official end date be added to the career of one of the most successful pop duos of all time? “You can ask Daryl the same question,” Oates says. “But, yes. As far as I’m concerned, I’ve moved on. I feel like I have a new lease on my creative life.”
He then picks up a book and begins reading a passage. “I’m basically a Taoist,” he says. “And I’m going to read you something that was in my daily meditation today. It says, ‘The rule for those who follow Tao is this, ‘Walk the path together as long as you can, and when you must part, never hold your companion back.'”
“That’s how I feel about things,” he continues. “A good friend of mine said something to me when this was all starting. He said, ‘John, you were a musician before you met Daryl, and you’re still a musician. You’re an individual.’ And Daryl and I have always called ourselves Daryl Hall and John Oates, because we always wanted to be perceived as two individuals who work together. That was very important to us. If you look at the albums, you’ll see that on every album. And so this is the ultimate expression of that.”
However, Hall and Oates were also best friends. They even lived in an apartment together. The name of the group came from what their landlord scribbled on their mailbox: Hall & Oates. While they may never play together again, Oates doesn’t rule out repairing their friendship.
“I’m always open for that,” he says. “Daryl Hall is an amazing individual. He is one of the great, great songwriters of all time, and without a doubt, one of the great singers of all time. I would never say anything negative about him. But we have a different strategy for our lives, and we have a different strategy for our business lives as well as our personal lives. And that’s that, so be it. We’re old guys. We deserve to be allowed to do whatever we want to do.”
Does he hope those old guys can one day perform one last song together to end the story on a positive note? “I have no idea,” he says. “But I don’t see it. I really don’t. Life is funny though. You never know what kind of curve it will throw you.”
